body_html:
I was able to open the _python_tensorflow_internal.pyd with Dependency Walker and it complained about cudnn64_5.dll not being found. I tried it on my command prompt and found that adding it to my path hadn't worked.

Fix for me was:

  1. Type "cudnn64_5.dll" into command prompt and get "not recognized" to verify that DLL wasn't in my path.
  2. Go back and add the location of the cudnn DLL to the path again (wherever you unzipped it to), making sure I clicked "OK" on the dialogs so that they close out correctly.
  3. Close my open command prompts.
  4. Open a new command prompt and type "cudnn64_5.dll", for me this opens NUnit since that is what opens DLLs on my setup.
  5. Activate my anaconda environment & run again.
  6. Bask in the fastness of GPU tensorflow!

Hope that helps @acburigo

Close my open command prompts.
Open a new command prompt and type "cudnn64_5.dll", for me this opens NUnit since that is what opens DLLs on my setup.
Activate my anaconda environment & run again.
Bask in the fastness of GPU tensorflow!

Hope that helps @acburigo
body:
I was able to open the _python_tensorflow_internal.pyd with Dependency Walker and it complained about cudnn64_5.dll not being found.  I tried it on my command prompt and found that adding it to my path hadn't worked.

Fix for me was:
1. Type "cudnn64_5.dll" into command prompt and get "not recognized" to verify that DLL wasn't in my path.
2. Go back and add the location of the cudnn DLL to the path again (wherever you unzipped it to), making sure I clicked "OK" on the dialogs so that they close out correctly.
3. Close my open command prompts.
4. Open a new command prompt and type "cudnn64_5.dll", for me this opens NUnit since that is what opens DLLs on my setup.
5. Activate my anaconda environment & run again.
6. Bask in the fastness of GPU tensorflow!

Hope that helps @acburigo
